heading: torvalds lays an egg
subheading: linus torvalds has a reputation as a funny, interesting speaker. but the lead developer of the linux operating system bored the pants off a few hundred people at a lotus developers' conference. leander kahney reports from san francisco.
author: leander kahney
text: san francisco -- his linux operating system may be going from strength to strength. and that's a good thing, because linus torvalds has little future as a speaker for hire. dramatically billed as "the most in-demand cyber-celebrity in the world today" at wednesday's lotus developers' conference 99, torvalds thoroughly bored a full house of lotus developers gathered to hear his keynote.in spite of his reputation for being witty and amusing, torvalds gave the audience of programmers and techies a lot of what they already knew, and in a droning monotone.see also: torvalds: preserve the 'f word'- - - - - -"it was a quite a lot of 'blah, blah, blah,'" said one disappointed attendee after the speech. "it wasn't quite what i was expecting."following a rapturous reception, people were soon staring at the floor, looking at their watches, and closing their eyes. in an otherwise silent auditorium, the sounds of coughing, fidgeting, stifled yawns, and whispered conversations were disproportionately amplified.instead of a string of clever wisecracks and laughs at the expense of microsoft, as most expected, the audience was subjected to 40 minutes of platitudes.in a speech entitled software development in a networked world, torvalds lectured the audience on what it knew already about the networks and software development. he revealed little about himself, linux, or the future of computer operating systems."the web is completely unstructured," torvalds told them, "there's no central control."adding insult to injury, torvalds then went on to dis the audience by unfavorably comparing the lotus development model to way things are done in the linux world.it didn't help that torvalds followed a polished speaker like evan schwartz. author of webonomics and a regular contributor to wired magazine, schwartz turned the potentially dry topic of web economics into an interesting and informative hour.whereas schwartz's talk was clearly laid out -- the salient points illustrated with concrete, real-world examples, and the whole thing sprinkled with interesting anecdotes and amusing jokes -- torvalds' droned on, backed by an endless series of amateurish text-only slides.ironically, for the author of a computer system lauded for its stability, torvalds' slides kept blinking off. he blamed himself. "i must learn to stop doing that," he said, without explaining what it was he was doing.to be fair, torvalds' talk picked up considerably during the q&a, where the programmer famous for steering a complex operating system through a collaborative development process clearly showed he thrived on interactive modes of communication.
